about and writing about housing
financial markets for a very long time
Nick good afternoon to each and every
one of you what I want to do just for a
couple of minutes is talk a little bit
about where we were where we are how we
got there and maybe between us we can
figure out where we might go from here
the roots of the modern housing finance
system in the United States began in the
New Deal when the when a number of
programs were put into place to address
the depression or as we in the housing
sector like to say the first Great
Depression and it was a dress it was
trying to figure out how best you could
make credit and liquidity available to
people buying a home before the
depression if you wanted to buy a home
it required a fifty percent down payment
that's 50 a five-year interest only note
and you'd cross your fingers you could
refinance at at the end of five years
clearly not many people own homes not
many people could borrow under those
terms under the New Deal a number of
programs were enacted that exists today
and in many ways undergird today's
housing finance system the Federal
Deposit Insurance Corporation ensuring
the deposit state and bank the Federal
Housing Administration which helped lead
to long-term mortgages and the national
mortgage association which eventually
evolved into Fannie Mae and that was the
system in the third
and it started to reopen credit lines to
people to buy homes and it pretty much
evolved fairly slowly in a pretty sort
of straight line with some cycles of
course into the 1980s in the 1980s the
traditional loan was made by a regulated
bank a deposit taking institution they
most often kept the loan on their books
retaining the credit risk but over time
they would sell more and more loans to
the secondary market particularly the
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac that it
evolved since then in order to relieve
themselves of some of the interest rate
risk so that's the way the world was in
the 1980s in the 1990s a couple of
things happen that really set the stage
for where we are today all of a sudden
there emerged automated underwriting
there emerged credit scoring and all of
a sudden the world of deposit taking
institutions your neighborhood bank all
of a sudden transform into these large
national mortgage banks a mortgage
delivery system that was populated by
brokers buy mortgage banks and by
investors it opened the door to new
sources of capital from around the world
holding that door wide open where Fannie
Mae and Freddie Mac by that time those
government corporations had become
private corporations but still overseen
by the government it's interesting as
one looks back to that period of time
one of the arguments from moving down
that path was not not only opening the
door to more liquidity but also it's
going to sound very very strange it's
less risky if we do it that way that
somehow if we don't keep all the risk
with these banks but we find a way as
Jay said the slice it and dice it parcel
it on who better than investors to
better assess better price and better
absorb that risk that was the argument
an ironic argument as we have learned
well all of a sudden that helped fuel a

that with
strong demographics people coming to

add low interest rates as we were seeing

you had the recipe for a pretty hot

somehow that should put a governor on

it represented a minimal share of home

these subprime loans started to emerge
it really wasn't a particular problem

as it relates to our housing finance

argument
in them in the middle of this decade we

overbuilt we estimate our center we
